Award.AwardTitle: From the Fundamental Lemma to Discrete Geometry, to Formal Verification
Award.AbstractNarration:
During June 18-22, 2018, the University of Pittsburgh will host an international conference entitled "From the Fundamental Lemma, to Discrete Geometry, to Formal Verification". The conference website can be accessed at http://www.mathematics.pitt.edu/hales60/. The aim of the conference is to explore the interface between the subjects listed in the title, with the primary focus on emphasizing similarities between different fields and finding new applications of existing techniques and methods from different areas. Major experts in each individual field will lecture on the main developments and applications, with the goal of making the ideas accessible to a non-expert audience. By bringing together researchers from the areas of Automorphic Forms, Motivic Integration, Discrete Geometry, and Formal Verification, we hope to highlight and deepen the connections between these areas.


Among other things, the conference will highlight the structural relationship between the classical geometric methods of partitioning space used to prove the Kepler conjecture and the new methods of harmonic analysis used to prove the sphere packing results in higher dimensions. In addition, the conference will attempt to bring together the Formal Verification community and the community of researchers working on the formal logic-based version of motivic integration. Both fields share similar techniques and the exchange of ideas between the two fields should be very fruitful. Formal verification of (broadly adopted) encryption standards is ultimately an issue pertaining to the foundation of society, and the involvement of the mathematical community in such efforts is absolutely crucial. The conference will feature a session on formal verification of encryption standards, including a public lecture on a recently verified NIST cryptographic standard. The Formal Abstracts project aims to provide a semantic representation of (ultimately all) mathematical knowledge accessible to the society, and many of participants of this conference are active members of the project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During June 18-23, 2018, the University of Pittsburgh hosted an international conference titled "From the Fundamental Lemma to Discrete Geometry, to Formal Verification". Organized to emphasize recent major developments in the respective fields and to make accessible the ideas and techniques that made them possible,  the conference was held in the honor of Thomas C. Hales on the occasion of his 60th birthday.  The conference was organized by Jeremy Avigad (Carnegie Mellon University), Henry Cohn (Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Microsoft Research), Julia Gordon (University of British Columbia), Michael Harris (Columbia University), Bogdan Ion (University of Pittsburgh), Chris Kapulkin (University of Western Ontario) and Woden Kusner (Vanderbilt University).


The objective of the conference was to bring together experts in the areas of Discrete Geometry, Representation Theory, Motivic Integration, and Formal Verification, giving many researchers an opportunity to learn about topics from outside of their area of specialization and to foster interaction between these groups. As attested by the work of Hales (among others) there are ideas and techniques that are common to all these areas and our aim was to highlight and deepen these connections. Among those in attendance, there were senior researchers, as well as many postdocs, and graduate and undergraduate students. Given the broad spectrum of subjects, we have asked the speakers to make their presentations accessible to a general mathematical audience, with the hope to facilitate new collaborations and to  make the ideas accessible to a non-expert audience.  Speakers and participants  from all across the United States, Europe and Asia attended the conference. 


The conference featured 23 talks on Discrete Geometry, Automorphic forms, Representation Theory, Motivic Integration, and Formal Verification. The program included a number of survey and overview talks accessible to wide audiences, such as Andrew Appel's lecture on  graph coloring and machine proofs in computer science, Sharon Glotzer's lecture on the material (nano)science of packing congruent regular tetrahedra, Tobias Nipkow's lecture on verified analysis of algorithms, and Josef Urban's lecture on automation and artificial intelligence for reasoning and formalization. Francois Loeser also gave a beautiful talk at the interface of motivic integration and representation theory, explaining the motivic nature of the orbital integrals that appear everywhere in the theory (e.g. in the Fundamental Lemma). The response from participants has been overwhelmingly positive.


Arguably, the largest group attending the conference was from the community interested in formal verification. Their participation galvanized and focused interest in the current major undertakings in the field (such as the Formal Abstracts project) and the development of the necessary logical and computational infrastructure (the Lean proof assistant). There where unique opportunities to interact with the community of researchers working on the formal logic-based version of motivic integration and with specialists in the fields in which many of the challenges for the Formal Abstracts projects lie in (motivic integration, automorphic forms, geometry, harmonic analysis). Formal verification of (broadly adopted) encryption standards is ultimately an issue pertaining to the foundation of society, and the involvement of the mathematical community in such efforts is absolutely crucial.
